abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Municipal Pension Reform
            Project (PREVMUN) for Brazil were as follows: outcomes were
            moderately satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            moderate, the Bank performance was moderately satisfactory,
            and the Borrower performance was also moderately
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included:  the
            participation of key political and technical actors at
            project design is helpful to ensure priorities are correctly
            defined and to promote ownership. This administratively
            difficult project ran relatively smoothly after the initial
            delays. The lack of major problems during implementation
            despite high political turnover at Ministry of Social
            Security (MPS) and the strong participation by
            municipalities in the exercises and training financed by
            PREVMUN reflects the high sense of ownership. Projects
            combining technical assistance to federal and municipal
            governments whose election cycles are not aligned will
            benefit from planning the implementation timing to avoid
            electoral periods. This could be achieved by starting after
            municipal elections, or from presenting plans for mitigating
            their potential effect as much as possible. Also, other
            political factors such as the risk of needing political
            actions outside the effective control of the implementation
            team (as the decree requiring pension management units to
            report the information using the Integrated Pension
            Information System (SIPREV) format) need to be looked at
            carefully. Relatively small operations at the federal level
            in Brazil absorb a relatively high amount of effort and
            supervision budget. However, this is partially because the
            Bank's rules and regulations require the same due
            diligence irrespective of loan amount. When needed for
            strategic reasons such as the social security reform at the
            time of the preparation of PREVMUN the Bank could consider
            simplifying procedures so that large and small loans are
            treated differently, thereby supporting the viability of
            smaller loans.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Municipal Pension Reform Project
            will upgrade municipal pension management, by addressing
            critical pension problems in crucial municipalities, and
            strengthening the capacity of the Ministry of Social
            Security and Assistance (MPAS/SPS), through the provision of
            technical assistance (TA), monitoring, and evaluation of
            pension management. To this end, project components will: 1)
            address institutional strengthening of the MPAS/SPS, in
            particular the Department of Public Social Security Systems
            (DEPSP), required to manage the project, and carry out its
            mandate of monitoring, evaluating, and providing TA to
            sub-national governments. TA will be provided through a core
            group of consultants in information technology, actuarial
            science, and pension legislation, which will be retained at
            DEPSP to supplement MPAS staff, and service municipalities
            during project implementation. A financial management
            specialist will provide project management support to
            administer the program, with an additional TA support for
            municipal logistics, including staff training. Institutional
            studies will be undertaken on pension fund asset management,
            and, for the evaluation and strategy assistance on municipal
            pension systems; and, 2) upgrade municipal pension
            management, and provide hardware/software, and related
            training to municipalities. Consulting services will be
            provided to upgrade municipal cadastre, through an actuarial
            analysis, and development of pension reform systems.
            Municipal dissemination, and workshops should enhance
            stakeholder participation on pension issues, and best
            practices to strengthen reform constituencies.
